abstract.p: Roberta Smith reviews Na'er Do Wells, group art show at DNA Studios (S)

block.p: This uneven, ecumenical grab-bag of a group show, the first in a funky ground-floor space that usually serves as an artist's studio, feels like the old East Village, which is in itself a startling and refreshing experience to have this late in the life of the SoHo art scene.

On view are a drawing and painted chair back by Jean-Michel Basquiat along with works by relative old-timers like Taro Suzuki and the writer Edit DeAk (showing fuzzy photographs) and restless up-and-comers like Tom Sachs and Hiroshi Sunari. But most of the names are new.

This uneven, ecumenical grab-bag of a group show, the first in a funky ground-floor space that usually serves as an artist's studio, feels like the old East Village, which is in itself a startling and refreshing experience to have this late in the life of the SoHo art scene.

On view are a drawing and painted chair back by Jean-Michel Basquiat along with works by relative old-timers like Taro Suzuki and the writer Edit DeAk (showing fuzzy photographs) and restless up-and-comers like Tom Sachs and Hiroshi Sunari. But most of the names are new.

Things to watch out for include Seth Quankmeyer's ''Celibacy Pants,'' which shows fiber art going punk (and is the result of a performance, not a macrame class); an equally crazed map of the world by an artist who goes by the name of Bug; the lovingly made little paintings of Sari Carel; Roth Belgum's photo essay on dogs (mostly their teeth); the woozy Goldinesque photographs of Gabriella Bass; and an energetic drawing by David Greenburg about ''the moment when memory grooves into childhood.''

The East Village-in-the-90's feeling is personified by a sculpture by Bob Partington: a conventional attache case rigged so that flicking a tiny lever enables its owner to surreptitiously ''tag'' any surface it rests on. These disparate efforts and others have been brought together by Alfredo Martinez and Jacob Williams.
